summary.p: Learned from Ambrosius Blarer that Bullinger and his family are doing well. His own situation has improved since the visitation, as the letter bearer, his brother-in-law, will report. Would like to come to Zurich himself and pick up the new writings [of Bullinger]. Apologizes for his inadequate writing due to the unexpected availability of a messenger. Greetings.

div.p: My entire humble service etc. to you (first), dear lord and teacher. I always like to hear that things are going well with your people etc., as I have heard from my lord and brother Ambrosius Blarer.

Although I have been in poverty, after the visitation [!] my situation (by God's grace) is well and well provided for. Although many challenges (temptations) have befallen me, God has made it better, as my dear brother-in-law, who is delivering this letter, will tell you etc.
If God wills, I would one day come to you and collect the copies you have written and made.

The reason I have written to you so inadequately is because my brother-in-law has taken another route for himself and intends to come to Zurich. With that, I thank God and you, who alone are responsible for all good things.
Given on Tuesday before Gallus' Day in the year 1536.
Greet Leon, Theodor, and all others etc.
To the well-learned M. Heinrich Bullinger, preacher in Zurich etc.
